content.rendered:
Maria wanted to see more results from her classes by energizing her alliances. For upcoming classes, her allies included:

  • the host
  • the presenter
  • people who answer questions
  • people who hand out brochures
  • any other teams that were invited so unlinked teams help each other

As she communicated with each ally, she made sure to listen carefully to what each ally wanted and then clearly explained what she would like. All agreed on a system that would benefit each other. With better communication, Maria’s host felt confident to invite more people. The presenter was able to focus on the presentation and did not have to worry about taking questions or getting handouts ready. Not only did classes begin to function better, but the results afterward were phenomenal. More people enrolled, more product was shared, the class was comfortable and fun, more growth happened because of the help the unlinked teams were giving each other, and Maria started to see more classes being scheduled and more people enrolling.

content.rendered:
The following are sample messages you could send when you create a new alliance and reinforce an existing relationship. Personalize them to fit your situation.

Forging a New Alliance

Dear blank,

I have been analyzing my business lately and have identified some things I need to improve on as a [consultant]. I definitely need some expert advice, and I see you as a very successful [leader/builder]. Would you be willing to meet with me and talk over a few things? I’d also like to offer my help with something you are working on.

You have a reputation for being very skilled at [holding meetings, signing new builders, and sharing products]. I have learned new [online techniques] that have proven very successful in attracting interest, and I think we can help each other. Working together will allow us to find new and better ways of [acquiring contacts and helping them become more successful].

Would you be willing to meet with me [this Friday at noon for lunch]? Let me know if that works for you, and we’ll schedule a place to meet.

Thanks, and I look forward to meeting with you.

Sincerely,
blank

Reinforcing an Existing Alliance

Dear blank,

I want to tell you how much I appreciate your willingness to work with me. I feel very grateful for the time you’ve taken to answer my questions. It was fun to collaborate, and I’m excited to continue working together. I especially appreciated the way you took the initiative and [sent me your top five ways to run a class and sign people up that night]. And I’m glad you were able to [use my top five ways of attracting new people and how to move them towards becoming a builder through various online sites].

Working with you has been a great learning experience for me, and I feel honored that you would take the time to help me. I look forward to working with you again as opportunities present themselves.

Sincerely,
blank

content.rendered:
Two forms of problem-reducing skills are needed to maintain healthy alliances:

Preventing Problems
This means making sure things run smoothly by organizing a problem-preventing strategy before problems occur. To prevent problems, make sure your intentions are clear and you have listened to what the other person wants. Communicate about both things as a reminder to both parties. Then communicate appreciation for people’s efforts and help.

Solving Problems
A three-part process is needed when problems do arise and the alliance is threatened.

  1. Assume that any problem is the result of poor communication and NOT due to an individual’s failures or inadequacy.
  2. Invite each party to communicate about the situation from his or her perspective. Remember to listen and focus on solutions.
  3. Without blaming, together address concerns, find a solution, and establish a trial time of trying to be more effective in your working relationship.

content.rendered:
Learning from others is a great way to increase your success. Learn best techniques and what to avoid to maximize results. Teaching great classes should be a major part of your strategy because classes are the primary source for product volume and enrollments. Take the time to learn as much as you can about teaching great classes.

Focus on all aspects of the class, and improve in these areas:

  • scheduling and advertising the class
  • encouraging the host
  • enticing and rewarding attendance
  • teaching about the product
  • introducing opportunities
  • inviting to act
  • closing
  • following up
  • teaching your team how to conduct fun, productive classes

MEASURE YOUR PROGRESS! If classes are not producing the results you want, don’t wait! Identify what you need to change or improve. Try something new, and test it to see if it works. Hold yourself accountable for presenting successful classes that produce great results.

content.rendered:
Using Handouts
If you wish to use product or kit handouts, be sure to use them effectively. Keep the number of handouts limited to the products or kits you will be presenting or to your class’s identified health goals so you don’t overwhelm and because people often order what is presented. Having contact information on handouts can be helpful in the event people don’t order at the class but have questions or want to order later.

NOTE: Even though you may not be teaching a “Business Opportunity” or “Loyalty Program” class, the topics may come up when closing a class, so be prepared with any handouts, charts, or pictures for these topics so you can better inform people. Again, keep it simple and relevant. For example, only provide a “loyalty program” handout if someone is asking multiple questions or showing a high level of interest. Otherwise, simply answer their question.

How well are you energizing your alliances (creating productive relationships with people who can help)?

How well are you building capacity?

Consider your answers, and identify the areas where you could improve.

content.rendered:
Measure Progress and Render an Account (part 2)

How to Measure Progress and Render an Account

Measuring progress means comparing your current results to your previous results (for example, comparing Week 2 to Week 1 in a certain area and then identifying how much improvement took place). Get reports often (at least weekly) to ensure that you identify what is working well and reinforce it and change what is not.

The following are seven key areas where you should be measuring progress. Measure week to week, and compare your progress as you go. Then answer the questions, “Why is this working? Why is it not?”

Volume
Measure your volume each week, and compare it with the previous week and the same week of the previous month. Measure volume shared with new enrollments, existing customers, and volume for a team or leg you are working to build.

Enrollment
Measure enrollment by the number of people who enroll each week from online contact, personal contact, referrals, and classes. Then compare with previous weeks.

Classes
Measure the progress of your classes by the number of people who enroll, the volume sold, and the number of new classes scheduled from each class you hold. Then compare with previous classes to see your progress.

Builders
Measure the progress of your builders by the amount of volume they share, number of builders who hit rank, and the number of new builders you enroll.

Customer Care
Count the number of people who report satisfaction this week, and compare it with the previous week. And/or count the wholesale customers or the number of people who purchased additional volume and compare.

Motivating Leaders
Record the number of people who accept and complete assignments, the number of people who complete the Jump Start training, the number of people who complete the Catalyst Leadership System training, the number of strategy maps created in Success Plus, the number of new people who produced at expected levels (or higher than expected) during the first thirty to sixty days, and compare with the numbers from the previous week and/or month.

Daily/Weekly/Monthly Habits
Track your daily, weekly, and monthly habits, and compare to see if the number of tasks you complete or results you achieve is increasing.

Render an Account

After the agreed-on amount of time, report your progress in these areas to your upline leader and other team members. Include the activities you’ve carried out, results/progress achieved, and how you feel about your progress. Render an account regularly so progress continues to improve.

content.rendered:
Measure Progress and Render an Account

Performance improves when it is measured and reported.

Why Measure Progress and Render an Account?
Do you have a step-by-step program to measure your progress, which also allows you to spend time with and support your family?

Measuring progress keeps you focused on innovation and helps you keep your priorities in the order you want them to be.

Are you able to identify specific reasons you are improving?

Measuring progress exposes both the most and least successful methods, allowing you to take advantage of success and quickly make changes to minimize the effects of failing efforts.

Do you and your team have a strong sense of achievement because you have taken the time to measure your progress and identify your successes?

Measuring progress and rendering an account brings your team together with a sense of shared achievement—helping everyone feel needed and motivating low performers to learn the methods high performers use.

Do you have goals but fail to focus and follow through?

Measuring progress and rendering an account enables you to stay focused on your goals and strategies, so you are able to achieve goals faster and more consistently.

What Is Measure Progress and Render an Account?

Measuring progress is more than getting reports about results. Measuring progress is how you tell whether what you are doing is effective. You increase your efficiency and performance when you pay attention to and measure what you are doing, assess whether it’s effective, and make changes.

Measuring progress is the dividing line between people who stay where they are and people who take control of their lives and make things better for themselves!

Rendering an account is simple! It means to voluntarily report to yourself and others about what you are doing and how things are going. When people freely tell one another about their progress, they feel empowered instead of imposed upon. Reports about success motivate and excite everyone, and failures allow people to support and unite. Your builders and leaders become more responsible when they render an account of their work.

Learn More

Learn More

Measure Your Ability to Innovate and Improve

The ability to innovate is so central to your work that it needs to be added to your system of measurement. Along with measuring your own and your team’s performance, also measure whether team members are developing increased capacity to innovate. Answer these questions for yourself or your team in order to measure your progress:

How well do you identify new ideas?

How well do you differentiate between good ideas and less-effective ideas?

How well do you foster a trusted and positive climate for new ideas?

How well do you shape an idea into a doable process?

How well do you test new ideas?

How well do you accurately assess both success and failure?

How well do you use both successes and failures to develop new or other innovative ideas?

Take a look at your answers, and consider where you could use improvement.

content.rendered:
When introducing the agenda, put people at ease by emphasizing that they are here to have fun and learn things that will help them and their family. There is no pressure to buy.

  • “Tonight, I’m going to show you some really great healthy-living alternatives that can help you with your personal and family health goals.”
  • “We’ll talk a little about the company because their standards and common practices are really what makes these products so amazing.”
  • “And then we’ll introduce you to some of the most popular products.”
  • “My part takes about 30-35 minutes. There is absolutely no requirement to buy, but if you’re interested in something, I’ll definitely help you find the best options. Just enjoy the night, and let’s have a great time.”

content.rendered:
• “I want to thank [host] for opening her home to us tonight. I love her passion for these products, and I’m so excited to be here. She loves the [recipes] and [creative ways to use the products], and we are so excited to share these ideas with you. We are going to have so much fun tonight.”
  • Use free gifts or drawings as incentives for people to host their own class. At the beginning of the class, pass out forms for a drawing you do at the end of class. Collect the forms at the end of class so people have the class time to learn more about the products and benefits of hosting their own class, which helps encourage more people to host.
    • “As a thank you to [the host], I brought her a [gift].”
    • If the host is someone not building a business and you are teaching the class for your own business: “I’m passing out these entry forms for anyone interested in receiving [a free gift] when they host a class. I’ll show you how easy it is, and you’ll see tonight how fun they can be for you and your friends.”
    • If the host is a new builder of the company: “[Host] is excited to begin building her own business. You’ll receive this [free gift] when you sign up to host a class, and you will really be helping [host] launch her business.”

content.rendered: Increase Your Success. Research has proven that when you write down goals (and even action plans in your strategies) and share them with someone (a mentor!), your success rate dramatically increases. And your strategies often improve because these people can provide insight you may not have recognized yet. With better strategies, you learn more and work more effectively—improving performance—so your success increases.

content.rendered: A powerful motivation for you and your future team of builders is to have a direction with selected outcomes that you think about every day and shape your strategy toward. Identify your purpose, and see it leading your efforts every day. Motivate your team by helping them visualize and work toward their goals.

content.rendered: Smart entrepreneurs understand the value of having a strong vision (or a defined direction) for yourself—both personally and for your business. Your vision can lift you up when you face challenges. Vision can push you when you ask yourself, “Why am I doing this?” And vision motivates others to believe in you and what you are trying to accomplish. Vision is power.

content.rendered:
At this stage, trust is a tremendous help to you for two reasons:

  1. Trust, when established, will allow you to help and enroll people easier and faster.
  2. Trust will make you more effective. When you build your business using trust, you are more relaxed, confident, and sincere. All of these traits lead to better results and greater success.

Making this list of people is an early step in creating your strategy. Foster trust by considering questions like these as you meet with people:

  • What are they like?
  • What conversations have you had?
  • What do these people say?
  • What are their visions and dreams?
  • Have you scheduled a follow up with them, and have you kept this schedule?

Pay attention to people! Listen more than you speak. Have their concerns in mind. As people recognize your sincerity and helpfulness, they will trust you more. And creating trust is the first step in being a strong leader.

content.rendered: Reading people isn’t a selling tool you use to get more of what you want. Reading people is a powerful tool to learn about others’ needs and match your products or services so you can provide greater service to improve these people’s situations. When you pay attention to how people are responding to you, watching their body language, listening to their tone of voice, or observing their emotions, you are fostering trust. And trust is an essential condition of being the type of high-performing leader who motivates others and succeeds in this business.

content.rendered:
More often than not, confident people are confident because they work at it. They work hard to be good at sales. They work hard at mastering their attitude. They work at improving their performance, and they help others improve theirs.

The best first step to build confidence is to create a plan. In what area(s) do you want to improve your confidence? Are you accepting new challenges? Are you trying things that are unfamiliar and learning from these experiences? Are you evaluating yourself and your situations, focusing on the positive (and what you can control), and learning what you can do to improve? Are you improving your skills? What is your plan?

content.rendered: “Better” implies difference. If you want better sales volume, you need to change something so you are doing things differently. View change as something positive because it means you are paying attention, learning, and improving. Then make your work more effective by measuring how well your plan is working and making changes that lead to improvements and eliminate ineffectiveness. Envision yourself as a successful salesperson who has the attitude of knowing what you want and creates a plan to achieve it. Then master your attitude so you ARE this type of person.
